nodes.text: Teacher quality has a substantial causal impact on elementary students' standardized test achievement and can be identified using teacher fixed effects in panel data

I use panel data linking students and teachers over up to 12 years in two contiguous New Jersey elementary school districts to estimate teacher fixed effects while controlling for student fixed characteristics and classroom variables

Regressions include student fixed effects, teacher dummy variables, a cubic in teacher experience (with an experience cutoff at ten years), school-year effects, and classroom controls (class size, split-level classroom indicators), with standard errors clustered by pupil
Identification assumptions: (a) grade effects are absorbed via grade-standardized NCE scores; (b) experience effects beyond a cutoff (ten years) are zero for identification of school-year effects

Data: nationally standardized basic skills tests (Reading Vocabulary, Reading Comprehension, Math Computation, Math Concepts) in years 1989-90 to 2000-01, NCE scale, student demographics, teacher credentials and experience; median student tested 3 times, many teachers observed in multiple classrooms

To test for nonrandom classroom assignment I examine past-score variation across current classrooms and compute dissimilarity indices of previous-classroom mixing; results indicate no systematic tracking and mixing similar to random assignment
Teacher fixed effects are jointly highly significant predictors of student test scores in all four subject areas (p-values < 0.001)

Classroom-specific observed variables (class size, classmates' prior average score, split-level class indicators) are generally not significant predictors of individual test scores when student and teacher fixed effects are included

A one standard deviation increase in estimated teacher quality raises reading test scores by ~0.20 SD and math test scores by ~0.24 SD on the national NCE scale (estimates derived from percentile differences in teacher fixed effects)

Controlling for teacher fixed effects, additional teaching experience raises reading scores: about a 4 NCE point (approx 0.2 SD) gain from zero to ten years in reading vocabulary and comprehension; math subjects show little consistent gain from experience

Estimates of experience effects that omit teacher fixed effects are biased: when teacher fixed effects are omitted, measured returns to experience are substantially smaller or insignificant, demonstrating correlation between experience and unobserved teacher quality

Pairwise correlations of estimated teacher fixed effects across subjects are positive (0.16 to 0.67): higher correlations among the three subjects excluding Vocabulary and lower correlations with Vocabulary, implying teachers' quality is generally positively related across subjects but not perfectly correlated

Variance decomposition bounds: teacher fixed effects and experience account for between about 1.1%-2.8% (lower bound) and 5.0%-6.4% (upper bound) of total test score variance by subject; expressed as share of policy-relevant variance (excluding measurement error and student-level variance) teachers explain roughly 4%-23% depending on bounds and subject

Given significant measurable teacher effects and limited predictive power of common credentials, policies focusing on performance-based indicators and incentives for teachers may be more effective than relying solely on credentials

Limitations: analysis is based on two similar New Jersey districts so external generalizability is uncertain; identification relies on assumptions about experience cutoff and absence of persistent omitted inputs; tests may not capture all aspects of teaching quality
